ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was focused on the policy implications of climate change and decarbonization.
I learned about different relationships, dynamics, and theories that shape environmental politics. I also learned how to write more theory-based essays.
How to think about the politics of the environment from a variety of perspectives, such as political polarization, psychology, sociology, epistemology, finance, national security
I learned a lot about environmental policies.

As someone with a prior interest in environmentalism, this course provided me with a great opportunity to frame my knowledge in a political context - and understand how the interactions between the public and private sectors to mitigate and solve climate change.
A holistic understanding of the interaction between politics and climate change action

This class gave me insight into the different systems of political, ecological, and economic competition involved in the wider understandings of environmental policy. We discussed both historical and present-day challenges to environmental policy, considering the unique institutions of the American government and the private sector.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was listed as a seminar but was more of a lecture. The professor seemed a little disorganized and the course material did not always relate to environmental issues. The final paper for the class was announced a week before it was due and it would have been nice to have known the requirements on the syllabus or at least a few weeks before.

The strength is the subject. It's a field of study that is growing ever more complicated, relevant, and interesting. There were several weaknesses of this course. It's a very disorganized class. The readings were all thrown into one folder and we often got our reading list 4-6 days before the seminar. The lecture slides were challenging to follow because it seemed to have no structure. The 'seminar' is like a lecture so you listen to Professor Swenson talk for an hour and then listen to your peers present for another. I think this class can be improved if these things are addressed. Also, the short essay instructions were very vague and he only sent me them after I asked. It would have been helpful to see a few student examples too. Overall, I think the class just needs more structure and more opportunities to discuss (like in a seminar).

Strengths: the readings were incredibly interesting. The paper assignments were also great exercises in helping you think about the weekly topic more deeply
Weaknesses: would have enjoyed more class discussion, since most of the class is spent as a lecture or listening to student presentations
It's hard to stay engaged in this course because it's half lecture, half student presentations. There is little to no participation outside of the two presentations a semester.

Strengths: well-structured and covered a wide variety of topics. Had something that suited everyones interests - from ecology to religion to finance
Weaknesses: while there are no major weaknesses with the course per se in my view, I would say a great addition to the course would be expanding the role of discussion among students in each seminar.
I feel that Professor Swenson could offer more opportunities for students to consult him on the feedback given for assignments
I think lectures could have been a bit more engaging and interactive. I found that if I wasn't presenting or asking questions to the presenters, many of us didn't get to speak in the seminar.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was essentially a normal seminar.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No, maybe the online format made it worse but some of the information was useful and interesting.

I am reluctant to. The subject is very interesting. Professor Swenson is also a very sweet professor. However, I feel like the class was very disorganized. I was not able to get much out of class because it was more like a lecture than a seminar. Also the slides were very confusing because no "content" slide was given so figures and words were just thrown at us. Moreover, Professor Swenson was often confused about why he put certain things in his slide deck so he was essentially winging every single class. Overall, the class did not meet my expectations even though I really wanted it to.
Yes, if you are interested in learning about the politics of the environment. If you do, you will really enjoy the readings and engaging with the argument paper assignments.
I generally wouldn't because while the material is interesting, there aren't a lot of opportunities to engage.

Absolutely. If youre interested in environmentalism and want to understand how it relates to partisan politics (and how that interacts with ecology, religion, finance, etc.) I would say that this course is an amazing way to explore that!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
NA
Virtual seminars with weekly presentations from 1-2 students
None
